qas.question: Why did Sichuan see some strongholds on the mainland?
Which government tried to make Burma its stronghold?

context: The Second Sino-Japanese War was soon followed by the resumed <b4_0>Chinese Civil War<b4_0/>, and the cities of East China <b5_0>fell to <a0_0><b9_0>the Communists<b9_0/><b5_0/><a0_0/> one after another, the <b6_0><b13_0>Kuomintang<b13_0/><b6_0/> government again tried to make Sichuan its stronghold on the mainland, although it already saw some Communist activity since <a3_0><b12_0>it was one area on the road of the Long March<b12_0/><a3_0/>. <a1_0><b7_0><b10_0>Chiang Kai-Shek<b10_0/><b7_0/><a1_0/> himself flew to Chongqing from Taiwan in November 1949 to lead the defense. But the same month <b8_0>Chongqing<b8_0/> fell to the Communists, followed by Chengdu on <a2_0><b11_0>10 December<b11_0/><a2_0/>. The Kuomintang general Wang Sheng wanted to stay behind with his troops to continue anticommunist guerilla war in Sichuan, but was recalled to Taiwan. Many of his soldiers made their way there as well, via Burma.
